text:

A food hygiene inspector criticised celebrity chef Andrew Nutter’s new restaurant for risking food contamination due to ‘poor practices in the kitchen’. 
The M.E.N. reported in January how The Bird at Birtle gastropub in Heywood was handed a one star food hygiene rating following an inspection on December 16. 
No reasons for the low rating were published at the time by the Food Standards Agency (FSA) but the M.E.N. has used Freedom of Information legislation to obtain the inspector’s full report. 
It shows the restaurant was using cling film dispensers and a vacuum packer for both raw meat and ready-to-eat foods and was ordered to stop by the inspector. Read More 
The day after the FSA’s visit, the restaurant purchased a second vacuum packer and new clingfilm dispensers, as well as plastic aprons - worn over normal aprons - and plastic gloves. Andrew Nutter, pictured earlier this year 
This week, Mr Nutter thanked customers for their loyalty since the inspection and told the M.E.N: “As we’ve previously stated, at The Bird at Birtle we take our health, safety and hygiene practices very seriously.” 
The restaurant was handed a food hygiene rating of one - the second lowest score - following the December inspection, which meant ‘major improvement’ was necessary. 
The inspector noted cleanliness in the kitchen was ‘reasonable could be better’ while food handling practices were criticised. 
They wrote: “Risk of indirect and direct cross-contamination due to poor practices in the kitchen.” The Bird at Birtle 
The report noted there were ‘no real controls in place’ in the kitchen’s ‘dual function area’ and suggested staff needed guidance on e-coli, a stomach bug, which ‘needs to be addressed’. 
The same clingfilm roll was being used for both cooked and ready-to-eat foods while there were no plastic aprons or gloves, says the report. 
It said there was inadequate procedure for cooling foods while notes at the end of the report again referred to ‘poor practices and controls’ in the use of the vacuum packing machine. 
Staff were ‘aware of all the issues and in some instances pointed them out’, according to the inspector, who adds: “Business has grown too quickly and management have not adapted to cope and adjust food safety procedures accordingly.” 
The restaurant was launched following a £1m transformation amid a fanfare in June with special guests including Coronation Street star Antony Cotton, Hollyoaks favourite Kieron Richardson, selfie queen Karen Danczuk. Karen Danczuk and Andrew Nutter at the opening of The Bird (Photo: Dominic Salter) 
A statement from Mr Nutter and his head chef Carl Tait added: “Upon the council’s first visit to our establishment we were scored well below the high standards that we set ourselves. Read More 
“We were missing numerous forms of documentation, training logs and risk assessments. This has now been rectified, all other recommendations that were provided to us at the time - the majority of which related to paperwork - have also been actioned. 
"The restaurant has also purchased additional kitchen equipment to exceed recommendations from the council. Andrew Nutter 
“We have worked closely with the council who have since revisited and are more than satisfied with the changes we’ve implemented. We are now awaiting a re-inspection. By law the council have to wait for three months before an official re-inspection can occur. They will then visit the establishment randomly to re-score. 
“At this point we hope to be achieving a rating that reflects our excellent processes and practices. 
“If any of our customers are concerned, we urge them to come and talk to us. We will happily show our them exactly how we work and the environment we work in. Finally, we would like to take this opportunity to thank all of our loyal customers and friends who have supported us over these challenging past few weeks.” Read More
